case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Raja of Chandapur Raj

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 238 of 1967 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 238 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 9. 1965

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment dated 9 February 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated February 9. 1965 of the Allababad High Court in Special Appeal No. 310 of 1960. N. Dikshit and O. P. Rana, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court dismissed appeal by State of Uttar Pradesh in Special Appeal No. 310 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: N. Dikshit and O. P. Rana, for the appellant. P. Goyal and R. A. Gupta, for the respondent. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ray, J.-This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment dated 9 February, 1965 of the High Court at Allahabad dismissing the appeal filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh

facts.text: Single Judge quashed assessments under Uttar Pradesh Large Land Holding Tax Act No. 31 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the learned Single Judge quashing the assessments of the respondent under the Uttar Pradesh Large Land Holding-, Tax Act No. 31 of 1957  hereinafter referred to as the Act  and further holding that the respondent was entitled to the benefit under rule 6-A

facts.text: Respondent held entitled to benefit under rule 6-A of Uttar Pradesh Large Land Holdings Rules 1957.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent was entitled to the benefit under rule 6-A of the Uttar Pradesh Large Land Holdings Rules. 1957  hereinafter referred to as the said Rules . The respondent Raja was prior to the abolition Of Zamindari in the State of Uttar Pradesh the Raja of the properties known a Chandapur Raj companysisting of 28 village,

facts.text: Respondent was Raja of Chandapur Raj consisting of 28 villages in Tahsil Maharajganj, District Rae Bareli.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Raja was prior to the abolition Of Zamindari in the State of Uttar Pradesh the Raja of the properties known a Chandapur Raj companysisting of 28 village, in the Tahsil Maharajoanj in the District of Rae Bareli. The respondent was a minor till 3 March, 1958

facts.text: Respondent was minor till 3 March 1958 and attained majority on 4 March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a minor till 3 March, 1958 and he attained majority on 4 March, 1958. The properties were under the management of the Court of Wards from 1945 to 1953 and thereafter under the management of the .District Judge, Rae Bareli tip to 4 March, 1958.

facts.text: Properties under management of Court of Wards from 1945 to 1953, then District Judge Rae Bareli till 4 March 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The properties were under the management of the Court of Wards from 1945 to 1953 and thereafter under the management of the .District Judge, Rae Bareli tip to 4 March, 1958. on 1 April, 1958 the Tax Assessment Officer, Maharajganj Sub-Division served a numberice under section 7  2  of the 1957 Act

facts.text: Notice under section 7(2) of 1957 Act served on 1 April 1958 for Fasli year 1365 (1 July 1957 to 30 June 1958).

anchor.surface_text: on 1 April, 1958 the Tax Assessment Officer, Maharajganj Sub-Division served a numberice under section 7 2  of the 1957 Act on the respondent for the assessment Fasli year 1365 companymencing on 1 July, 1957 and ending on 30 June, 1958. The respondent was required by the said numberice to file a return

facts.text: Respondent filed return claiming exemption under rule 6-A for agricultural land sub-let to tenants under orders of Court of Wards and District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: for the agricultural year of the land holding of the respondent. The respondent filed a return and claimed benefit of exemption under rule 6-A of the said Rules in respect of the agricultural land which had been sub-let to tenants under the orders of the Court of Wards and the District Judge

facts.text: Sub-Divisional Officer Maharajganj on 16 July 1958 dismissed claim and assessed tax at Rs. 62,011.39.

anchor.surface_text: when the respondents properties were under their management. On 16 July, 1958 the Sub-Divisional Officer, Maharajganj being the Assessing Officer dismissed the respondents claim for exemption in respect of the land holding sub-let and passed an assessment order imposing tax on the land holding of the respondent for the sum of Rs. 62,011.39.

facts.text: Respondent claimed assessment should be Rs. 34,274-6-10 after exemption under rule 6-A.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated that the assessment according to the respondent should have been Rs. 34,274-6-10 as a result of the exemption under rule 6-A. Tile respondent preferred an appeal before the Commissioner, Lucknow Division.

facts.text: Appeal to Commissioner Lucknow Division dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Tile respondent preferred an appeal before the Commissioner, Lucknow Division. The appeal was dismissed. On 9 September, .1958 the Commissioner held that rule 6-A was number applicable to assessment of tax for the 1365 Fasli year.

facts.text: Commissioner on 9 September 1958 held rule 6-A not applicable for Fasli 1365.

anchor.surface_text: On 9 September, .1958 the Commissioner held that rule 6-A was number applicable to assessment of tax for the 1365 Fasli year. The respondent thereafter on 29 September, 1958 filed a writ petition in the High Court at Allahabad challenging the validity of the Act

facts.text: Writ petition filed on 29 September 1958 in Allahabad High Court challenging Act and assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter on 29 September, 1958 filed a writ petition in the High Court at Allahabad challenging the validity of the Act and for quashing the assessment orders. The learned Single Judge of the Allahabad High, Court on 29 February, 1960

facts.text: Single Judge on 29 February 1960 held Act valid, entitled to rule 6-A, quashed assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Single Judge of the Allahabad High, Court on 29 February, 1960 held that the Act was valid and allowed the writ petition in part by holding that the respondent was entitled to the benefit of rule 6-A and therefore quashed the assessment order.

facts.text: U.P. Large Land Holding Tax Act 1957 came into force on 1 July 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The, 1957 Act came into force on 1 July, 1957. Section 29 of the Act empowered the State Government to make, rules for carrying out the purposes of the Act. The rules were published in the U.P. Gazette, Extraordinary dated 23 November, 1957.

facts.text: Rules published in U.P. Gazette on 23 November 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The rules were published in the U.P. Gazette, Extraordinary dated 23 November, 1957. Rule 6-A was added to the Rules by an amendment on 23 April, 1958.

facts.text: Rule 6-A added by amendment on 23 April 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 6-A was added to the Rules by an amendment on 23 April, 1958. The companytention on behalf of the State was that because rule 6-A was number made retrospective with effect from 1 July, 1957

facts.text: Respondent was disabled land-holder under section 157 of U.P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a disabled land-holder within the meaning of section 157 of the Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950. The land had been lawfully sub-let while the properties were under the management of the Court of Wards

facts.text: Land was lawfully sub-let while properties under management of Court of Wards and District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The land had been lawfully sub-let while the properties were under the management of the Court of Wards and thereafter the District Judge. The companytention of the appellant that the respondent became a major on 4 March, 1958

facts.text: State did not dispute legality of sub-letting in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The second companytention of the State that the land had number been legally sub-let cannot be entertained. In the High Court the State did number dispute the legality of sub-letting. It is, therefore, number, open to the State to raise that companytention.

issues.text: Whether the respondent was entitled to the benefit of rule 6-A for the assessment of tax on the annual value of land holding for the agricultural year commencing on 1 July, 1957, given that rule 6-A did not come into existence until 23 April, 1958

anchor.surface_text: First, it was said that tax was to be, assessed on the annual value of land holding as on 1 July, 1957 and inasmuch rule 6-A did number come into existence on 1 July, 1957 the respondent was number entitled to the benefit of the rule.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, it was said that rule 6-A was number at all applicable, because it was number proved that the land was lawfully sub-let.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was wrong in issuing the writ on the ground of misconstruction of rule 6-A by the assessing authorities, because it was not a patent error

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, it was said that the High Court was wrong in issuing the writ on the ground of misconstruction of rule 6-A by the assessing authorities because it was number a patent error.

holdings.text: Rule 6-A is applicable to the tax assessment for Fasli year 1365 despite being added on 23 April 1958 after the year commenced on 1 July 1957

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the State was that because rule 6-A was number made retrospective with effect from 1 July, 1957 but that rule 6-A came into existence on 23 April, 1958, the said rule would number be applicable in respect of assessment companymencing 1 July, .1957. This contention is unacceptable as it is unsound.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural rules under s29 apply to assessments made after their effectiveness for the entire agricultural year to avoid absurdity, as initial rules were notified after Act commencement

holdings.text: The respondent was a disabled land-holder within the meaning of section 157 of the Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a disabled land-holder within the meaning of section 157 of the Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950. The land had been lawfully sub-let while the properties were under the management of the Court of Wards

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fits statutory definition as minor under Court of Wards management prior to abolition

holdings.text: The contention that the respondent could not get benefit of rule 6-A because he attained majority on 4 March 1958 is untenable

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellant that the respondent became a major on 4 March, 1958 and therefore he could not get benefit of the rule is untenable. Rule 6-A refers to land which has been legally sub-let.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 6-A applies to land legally sub-let prior to rule (anterior to 23 April 1958)

holdings.text: Rule 6-A is to be read with sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Act and respondent entitled to its benefit for sub-let land in assessing annual value for Fasli 1365

anchor.surface_text: Rule 6-A is to be read with sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Act, The assessment was for the entire agricultural year from 1 July, 1957 up to 30 June, 1958. The land which had been lawfully sub-let could not be in the possession of the respondent in the assessment year. Therefore in assessing the land holding for the year 1365 Fasli the respondent was entitled to claim benefit under Rule 6-A in respect of land which had be-en legally sub-let.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction for computing annual value; benefit enures to character of land holding during year

holdings.text: Rules under the Act including rule 6-A are procedural and apply to assessments made after they come into effect even for years commencing earlier

anchor.surface_text: Rules are procedural. Rules relate to the assessments. The assessment is for the entire year. The assessment in the particular instance was made after rule 6-A came into effect. The assessment was pursuant to notice which was delivered on 1 April, 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules carry out Act purposes like return filing and annual value computation; non-application would be absurd given rules post-dated Act start

holdings.text: The contention that land had not been legally sub-let cannot be entertained as State did not dispute it in High Court

anchor.surface_text: The second contention of the State that the land had number been legally sub-let cannot be entertained. In the High Court the State did number dispute the legality of sub-letting. It is, therefore, number, open to the State to raise that contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State estopped from raising point not argued before High Court

holdings.text: High Court justified in issuing writ under Art 226 for misconstruction of rule 6-A as it involves statutory construction

anchor.surface_text: The third contention of the State that there is numberpatent error and therefore the High Court was wrong in issuing a writ is unacceptable. The respondent Raja raised a contention as to the application of rule 6-A. This is a question of construction of the statute and rules in respect of assessment. The High Court was justified in issuing the writ.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question of law on rule application justifies writ; patent error not required

anchor.surface_text: Rule 6-A is to be read with sections 3, 4 and 5 of the Act, The assessment was for the entire agricultural year from 1 July, 1957 up to 30 June, 1958. The land which had been lawfully sub-let could not be in the possession of the respondent in the assessment year. Therefore in assessing the land holding for the year 1365 Fasli the respondent was entitled to claim benefit under Rule 6-A in respect of land which had be-en legally sub-let.
The High Court was justified in issuing the writ.
